elements.title: Maria Trubnikova (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that after dying in her daughter's arms in an asylum in 1897, Maria Trubnikova (pictured) was remembered as the "heart and soul" of feminist activism in Russia?

elements.title: Lake Fenwick (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Lake Fenwick suffers from an infestation of Brazilian elodea?

elements.title: besieging Baghdad in 1258 (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that before besieging Baghdad in 1258, the Mongol prince Hulegu Khan ended a letter to the city's ruler with the words "I will show you the meaning of the will of God"?

elements.title: Kips Bay Towers (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that after the original developer of the Kips Bay Towers sold off the buildings in 1962, his son bought them back a decade later?

elements.title: Mwaksy Mudenda (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Mwaksy Mudenda presented her first Blue Peter episodes in her house?

elements.title: Milwaukee Brewers ball-in-glove logo (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that CBS Sports said the Milwaukee Brewers ball-in-glove logo "might just be the best in all of baseball"?

elements.title: anti-facial recognition masks (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the use of high-tech surveillance to monitor protests and identify participants has led protestors to use anti-facial recognition masks?

elements.title: Tarcisio Martina (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Tarcisio Martina, the representative of the Holy See in China, was sentenced to life imprisonment in 1951 over a plot to assassinate Mao Zedong?
